results.title: Depression. Addiction
results.creator_credit: Michael Custance, Annie Moore, B-line Productions and Discovery Networks Europe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Alternative”.
This episode of the fifteen part television series on complementary health focuses on two separate segments: “Depression” (and stress) and “Addiction”. In the first segment on depression, a brief definition and explanation of how and why this emotional illness can cause so much grief, physically and psychically. Explains ‘Melancholic’ and ‘Atypical’ depression and the fact that stress can also be attributed and/or linked to depression. Suggests that learning a better response to depression rather than just trying to cure it would be far more beneficial. By using case studies, the following areas of therapy are discussed and demonstrated: Hypnotherapy; Colour therapy; Reflexology and flower remedy therapy; the Journey therapy. The second segment deals with various forms of addiction with a brief explanation of why some people suffer from this disease (10% of the population have addictive or compulsive behavior problems) and why others don’t. Through various case studies, it covers cannabis, food and alcohol addiction with discussion and demonstration of the following therapies: Homeopathic and Shamanic practice; Hypnotherapy and nutrition; Chinese medicine including acupuncture, Qi Gong and herbal therapy. Commentary by Dilly Barlow.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Custance, Annie Moore, B-line Productions and Discovery Networks Europe

results.title: Back pain. Migraine
results.creator_credit: Serena Macbeth, Annie Moore, B-line Productions and Discovery Networks Europe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Alternative”.
This episode of the fifteen part television series on complementary health focuses on two separate segments: “Back pain” and “Migraine”. Dealing with back pain first, it is said that two-thirds of the population in the United Kingdom suffers from this physical ailment and that it is the second most common problem after heart disease. Back pain is usually caused through spinal disorders from accidents, sport injuries and work related physical stress. Treatment can be obtained from a range of practitioners including Osteopaths, Chiropractors, Physiotherapists and non-surgical medical practitioners. Using case studies, the following areas of therapy are discussed and demonstrated: Alexander technique/swimming; Osteopathy; Bowen technique; Electro-crystal therapy; Pilates. The second segment covers migraines which can be triggered off through various reasons including over exertion or stress causing tightness in the muscles. 60% of migraines are caused by displaced vertebrates in the cervical spine and can consist of many different symptoms, including headache, nausea, aversion to light and sound, vomiting, tiredness, It usually affects half the head and can sometimes create a sensititvity to alcohol, citrus, cheese, chocolate and other food types. The following areas of therapy are discussed and demonstrated: Magnet therapy; Osteopathy; 5-Element acupuncture; integrated treatment including therapeutic yoga, relaxation, breathing exercises, specific neck and spine exercises. Commentary by Dilly Barlow.

results.title: Psychology Live
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Memory
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Psychology Live”.
This program looks at various theories of memory and the importance of memory. Although tailored to year 12 and tertiary Psychology students, its information is of general interest and contains several practical exercises and self-tests. The presenters support the “ecological approach” of cognitive psychology, which values the research done in situations of everyday life, not just in laboratories. It examines three main types of memory: episodic, semantic and procedural, as well as the processes of encoding, storage and recall of information. Memory theory as developed by both Herman Ebbinghaus and Frederick Bartlett is explained, along with more recent theory of Parallel Distributed Processes (PDP). Theories of forgetting are outlined, including trace decay, interference, amnesia and repressive memory as well as context and state dependency. Practical techniques for assisting memory (mnemonics) are outlined and demonstrated. Study notes included.

results.title: Classical and operant conditioning
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Psychology Live”.
This program looks at theories of learning, particularly those of Classical and Operant Conditioning. Although tailored to year 12 and tertiary Psychology students, the program’s information is of general interest and contains several practical exercises, real life demonstrations and self-tests. The presenters support the “ecological approach” of cognitive psychology, which values the research done in situations of everyday life, not just in laboratories. Following an introduction to the study of behaviourism, this program discusses in detail the theories and terminolgy of past and present theories of behaviorism including I.P. Pavlov’s Classical Conditioning and B.F Skinner’s Operant Conditioning. The studies these researchers undertook are outlined and commented on, including the ethical issues regarding their work such as the animal experimentation issues associated with Pavlov’s dogs. The theories are then compared and assessed and discussed in terms of relevance and application in contemporary studies of learning and behaviour. Study notes included.

results.title: Cognitive development
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Psychology Live”.
This program looks at theories of cognitive development over time from the theories of Jean Piaget to those of Jerome Bruner and assesses their contribution to both past and present research into cognitive development and to educational practices. Although tailored to year 12 and tertiary Psychology students, the program’s information is of general interest and contains several practical exercises, real life demonstrations and self-tests. The presenters support the “ecological approach” of cognitive psychology, which values the research done in situations of everyday life, not just in laboratories. This program focuses on introducing the theories of Jean Piaget, his notion of schema, assimilation, accommodation, and equilibration as well as his theory of the stages in cognitive development. His methodology is then explored in detail along with a discussion of recent research findings which disagree with his. Jerome Bruner’s theory and modes of representing the world is then introduced, compared with Piaget’s theories, particulary in relation to the role of language in cognitive development, and included in a discussion of the future of the study of cognitive development in relation to recent research in metacognition and the theory of the mind. Study notes included.

results.title: Waterworks
results.brief_description: ‘Waterworks’ is an in depth series produced by the ABC on water and covers areas such as; human usage, molecular properties and the role of water in the ecology.

results.title: Taps and toilets
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Waterworks”.
Episode 4, ‘Taps and toilets’, deals with how human usage plays a role in the water cycle. Areas of human usage (both industrial and domestic) are discussed from the source point to the processes used for the purification of waste-water. Increased demand for water has highlighted long-standing problems with water supply including pollution. Forms of pollution discussed are tree clearing, salination and rainwater (carrying pesticides etc to our bays). Also discussed are unconfined aquifers (which explains our Billabongs), and confined aquifers like the Artesian Basin. Narrated by writer and producer Dick Beilby, this program creates relationships between our use of water and broader climatic environment beyond the taps and toilets - “the part of the water cycle that mostly connect with our lives”.

results.title: Floating, sinking, swimming
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Waterworks”.
‘Floating, sinking and swimming’, the third in the series, primarily deals with physics principles that explain the nature of water in relation to our use of it. The rules for floating and sinking are discussed, with Archimedes’ Principle that went further to describe the physics of buoyancy. Pressure, force and density are explained with examples (like the construction of wetsuits and submarines) that differentiate how water pressure relates to solids and liquids. Presented by series producer Dick Beilby.

results.title: Amazing H2o
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Waterworks”.
‘Episode 2: amazing H2O’ starts with the story of Henry Cavendish (Mark Allen), a rich scientist in the 17th century who made it his mission in life to discover the properties of water. His persistence gave us the H2O chemical name. With 70% of the earth covered in water, it is surprising to learn that scientists know more about the qualities of ice than water itself. Exploring both the realm of the known and unknown, this episode covers the following topics; surface tension, anti-gravitational behaviour, solutions, emulsions, ice, gas, evaporation, crystals. Presented by series producer Dick Beilby.
